This is a really fantastic, addictive game, and I really recommend it if you enjoy narrative-style rpgs and political sims, but like, applied to a bigger scope. The framing of the story is that you will be slowly rebuilding your ‚Äúdynasty‚Äù, after a nation-wide rebel invasion killed off most of your clan members and destroyed your estate: you start with one clan member, horrible stats and no money, progressively amassing power and influence‚Äîto the point you could easily stage a coup and supplant the Emperor (if you so choose). 
The game gives you a lot of freedom to try different playstyles and approaches to the problems you face: you can go for the military route, sending your characters to conquer the surrounding provinces, or have them enter public service via provincial examinations; although realistically you should be going for both to reach higher renown and such. (In theory, sending your characters to war should be a gamble, since they run the risk of dying in battle, but in practice none of my characters ever died because of it, even with low stats.) 
Since your interests are spread out over many different clan members, the game isn‚Äôt afraid of dishing out pretty realistic consequences for your actions, either. If you try and fail to assassinate a royal clan-member, the character who attempted assassination will be executed and your relationship with the royal family will take a hit, but it‚Äôs not like it‚Äôs a game-breaking thing. This way, mistakes and failures actually become a gateway for more content and interactions, and these unpredictable ups and downs make the story even more realistic and ‚Äúalive‚Äù, if that makes sense. Events also happen at a time scale of generations, which gives a pretty organic feel to your progression through the ranks. 
What I loved the most is how interactive the game feels: there‚Äôs a lot of RNG events that can happen at key moments, which sometimes make or break the narrative you were building towards. Marriages are one of the easiest ways of building strong relationships with other clans, so you catch yourself thinking really pragmatically about it, almost like a C-Drama villain. 
(‚ÄúYou‚Äôre 18, Ge clan‚Äôs Huer Ge‚Äôs 18, they have a Chancellor in court, can I make it any more obvious?‚Äù)
Even so, while you can make plans for them, characters will sometimes get really interesting bursts of agency‚Äîask to divorce from the Royal Family because life in the palace is making them miserable, fall in love with someone in a party they were invited and move in together, have an affair with their partner‚Äôs third cousin‚Ä¶. I think these are really neat, and I‚Äôm always positively surprised by these events. 
That being said, there are a lot of features that are still being implemented, so some parts of the gameplay will feel ‚Äúmissing‚Äù, or the late-game can feel a little still. Other problems are QOL, like multiple sub-menus, but the update roadmap shows there are on their way to being fixed. Personally, one thing that bothers me is that once they pass away, clan members go missing from the family tree, and all the connections they used to have disappear. This can make it even harder to track who is who, especially when the number of people in your clan reaches a hundred. I imagine this is made to avoid using up too much processing power (which is an admirable effort, the game runs pretty well on my 8yo laptop), but it would still be nice to have some way of keeping track of your complete family line, maybe with the portraits of deceased members greyed out?
All in all, I really enjoyed playing it so far, and I‚Äôm looking forward to the next updates!

House of Legacy is a game with tremendous potential, especially for players who are interested in the rich history and culture of China. From the very beginning, the game manages to capture the essence of political dynamics among noble families, while also reflecting the cyclical rise and fall of dynasties throughout Chinese history.

The features provided so far are quite promising and succeed in building an immersive atmosphere of strategy and historical intrigue. Players are able to experience how alliances, rivalries, and conflicts shape the path of power, offering a fascinating glimpse into the complexities of imperial politics. This layer of depth makes the game stand out as more than just a casual simulation‚Äîit feels like a window into the historical struggles that defined ancient China.

That being said, House of Legacy still has a wide space for further development. Expanding on career progression systems, adding more intricate details to events, and enriching interaction options between characters would significantly enhance the overall experience. With continuous updates, the game could evolve into one of the most compelling titles in the genre of historical strategy and simulation.

Overall, House of Legacy is undeniably addictive. Its combination of immersive gameplay, strong cultural flavor, and vast potential for growth makes it a highly engaging experience for those who appreciate history, politics, and the cultural richness of China.

- There are dozens of ways to interact with characters but there's little reason to do any of them except arranging marriages

- Fiefdoms seem to be granted randomly and are the only way to raise a private army afaict
- I still have no idea how the royal family system works

Great idea and execution, but severely needs Quality of Life changes... Especially for people who do not have fully functioning hands. There is a lot of clicking required to get started in many games, but here, there is no way to decrease the clicking.

Want to fix up your mansion? Click on every single tile until you find the ones you can repair, then click, click, click to reorient the parts of the house you want to place.

I would be happy to give it another shot if they improve accessibility, but at this point, its a "no for me, dawg"

I wouldn't recommend it yet. The game is very beautiful, there seem to be a ton of layers to it and interacting mechanics... but like many Chinese games I've played it is a bit overdeveloped and under-explained. My biggest problem with the game right now is that it doesn't explain how to play it. In my short trial I found myself in the Discussion forums at least three times... and everything I looked for had multiple threads asking the same questions.

What is stamina? Where am I supposed to see it? When does it refresh? Is there some activity I can undertake to get more? 
(It limits what your character can do, you can see it on the character screen ONLY which is very inconvenient UI, it refreshes at the start of the in game month, I have no idea)
Why am I dying? It says I have low health, but I haven't fought anyone... (I guess I was starving? It isn't explained well that you need a certain amount of provisions each month in order to survive at all. There aren't meters anywhere... you just have to check your character screen. I had no idea I needed to assign myself to a house after I repaired it.)

I also checked the Discussions to see if anyone else found the game to be incredibly slow... My experience was tedious. I was looking for things to buy low, selling them high, repeat... every month. I just learned I could build a store and I guess that would have given me some passive income, but the beginning is really rough. I felt like I was always tired and starving and it just took so long to crawl out of that hole. I did take out a bank loan, and was able to pay it back... but eventually strangers showed up claiming to be my family so I had to fix more buildings and feed them... so I had to take out another loan...

I'm sure I would have been successful EVENTUALLY, but it felt like basically none of the gameplay was explained in a way that would set me up for success. The tutorial was extremely short, so it could definitely afford to be longer! Teach me about stamina, time progression, what a retainer is and what they can do for you, why my female family member couldn't work, why my retainer couldn't act as a domestic servant, or really ANYTHING else. 

I have high hopes for the game, but for now I'll take a refund and wait to see if it gets better.

I wouldn't recommend it yet. The game is very beautiful, there seem to be a ton of layers to it and interacting mechanics... but like many Chinese games I've played it is a bit overdeveloped and under-explained. There are a few translation issues which complicate things... for instance 'Sell' and 'Acquire' are used incorrectly in some screens (which is very confusing for a merchant)... but mostly I didn't find localization to be an issue. 

My biggest problem with the game right now is that it doesn't explain how to play it. In my short trial I found myself in the Discussion forums at least three times... and everything I looked for had multiple threads asking the same questions.

What is stamina? Where am I supposed to see it? When does it refresh? Is there some activity I can undertake to get more? 
(It limits what your character can do, you can see it on the character screen ONLY which is very inconvenient UI, it refreshes at the start of the in game month, I have no idea)
Why am I dying? It says I have low health, but I haven't fought anyone... (I guess I was starving? It isn't explained well that you need a certain amount of provisions each month in order to survive at all. There aren't meters anywhere... you just have to check your character screen. I had no idea I needed to assign myself to a house after I repaired it.)

I also checked the Discussions to see if anyone else found the game to be incredibly slow... My experience was tedious. I was looking for things to buy low, selling them high, repeat... every month. I just learned I could build a store and I guess that would have given me some passive income, but the beginning is really rough. I felt like I was always tired and starving and it just took so long to crawl out of that hole. I did take out a bank loan, and was able to pay it back... but eventually strangers showed up claiming to be my family so I had to fix more buildings and feed them... so I had to take out another loan...

I'm sure I would have been successful EVENTUALLY, but it felt like basically none of the gameplay was explained in a way that would set me up for success. The tutorial was extremely short, so it could definitely afford to be longer! Teach me about stamina, time progression, what a retainer is and what they can do for you, why my female family member couldn't work, why my retainer couldn't act as a domestic servant, or really ANYTHING else. 

I have high hopes for the game, but for now I'll take a refund and wait to see if it gets better.

The art is nice and the concept sounds great - it has some city building aspects and Crusader Kings-like dynasty management and grand strategy. Unfortunately, it's just overambitious but underbaked at this point, with too many confusing and useless options, poor balance, and an unintuitive interface, especially for character interactions. Case in point:

- In cities and estates, placement of buildings doesn't matter at all. There are sprites walking around but they're just decorative.
- Shops offer jobs, but the rewards are meaningless after just 10-20 minutes of gameplay
- There are dozens of ways to interact with characters but there's little reason to do any of them except arranging marriages
- A single 16-acre farm can earn as much as an entire city or province
- Fiefdoms seem to be granted randomly and are the only way to raise a private army afaict
- I still have no idea how the royal family system works

If the devs cut down on some of the meaningless grind and spend more time refining the mechanics that matter, then this will be an easy recommend.

I rarely do game review, but this one is quite the problem. There is need to be a substantial rework on how the Royal capital work. The royal capital will always bankrupt everytime one of your family sit on the minister position, which in this case war minister is the easiest one to get. This would ruined the game and make it into a screeching halt, where the capital cannot go on war > which make no one able to progress further in rank/military > which mean that if all of your clan member that already have some military experience die due to various cirmustances, there wont be another way to progress the game. I get it that we don't have to rely on the capital for troops, and that we can utilize the province as a means to support our campaign, but the fact that the initial recruitment to get into the military can only be done through joining imperial campaign simply mean a doomed nation(unplayable game) when there isn't any left.  I get it that the game is still in early access but atleast make it so that all content already in the game are available to be obtained, and not to be hindered by some bullshit of a system that royal capital is.

So many clicking actions for so little impact. Why does a management game with so many moving parts require you to click for each one?

This was only within the first couple hours with 3 characters, 1 shop, 1 farm. The game shows windows with 10s of characters, it'd get crazy.

Great idea and execution, but severely needs Quality of Life changes... Especially for people who do not have fully functioning hands. There is a lot of clicking required to get started in many games, but here, there is no way to decrease the clicking.

To do interactions, you need to click through multiple menus. There is no automation, so you need to click to do everything. Want to sell stuff? Click on everyone to buy low and sell high. Want to fix up your mansion? Click on every single tile until you find the ones you can repair, then click, click, click to reorient the parts of the house you want to place.

I would be happy to give it another shot if they improve accessibility, but at this point, its a "no for me, dawg"

It's a fun game in the current state. Feel free to buy it on sale, but I would wait to really get into when they update a few core mechanics. I got bogged down searching through civilians for specific retainers and spouses (you can organize by stats/skills, but I hesitate to play this game until you can specify parameters - especially since a similar system is already implemented elsewhere). It really feels like a gotcha, gambling game, especially in the early stages. Not a lot of tutorials either on general politics, what can be achieved, and how - I've had to browse online threads to figure out how the game works. Definitely check it out later as they regularly update the game.

One of the most confusing games I've ever played. When an event happens to someone outside your clan occurs, good luck finding where they are on the map. Open the map and you can no longer access the event. Yihui Wang of Royal Family and Shuyu Yang of Yang Clan of Yingyang are suspected of forming cliques, you say? Let me open the map. I see Yang Clan, click on it, but no one mentioned in the event is listed to interact with. Maybe I'll try looking at the Royal Family. Nope not there either.

I don't get the positive reaction to this game.

I would have refunded it but just broke the 2 hour mark.

Audio: there is very little sound and as for music there is literally ONE track that loops, not a particularly long track either.

Game play: You work random jobs for your first money only needing to buy a little food. Doesn't take long to get enough to purchase your first business, a general store. Level one businesses earn enough 'revenue' to pay for themselves in 2 MONTHS (maybe 5 minutes real time). I say 'revenue' because you don't need to produce or acquire the products you sell in any of the businesses. You get the products for free so 'revenue' is all profit, there is only a minimal fee for workers.

There may be some deeper diplomacy farther into the game, it looks like it might run a bit like 'The Guild' games. but the economy is so broken it doesn't matter what else is going on. You generate vast sums of money with very little effort and there is almost no upkeep. It's basically a money clicker game, click things until you run out of stamina, buy passive income, click until out of stamina, wait to get enough renown for the next business unlock and buy it. rinse and repeat.

I discourage anyone from spending their money on this unless they completely rebalance this. Unless you don't want a game with any sort of challenge i guess.

I don't understand the point of this game. What's the end game? Just matchmaking characters? I conquered the Royal palace. I only have 3 provinces open. Building more farms is tedious, the blueprint system doesn't let you save. It does not cover Artisans in the default blueprints, so useless mid game. Selling stuff every year is tedious, cause you need to sell surplus but keep random snacks for whatever reason. 

Attack system - you can't attack unless someone invites you, or if you have a military title. You only get the military title if someone invites you to attack and you win. So you sit there with 10 characters with >80 might, being "invincible", just doing nothing. What is the objective here? 

Retinue management is tedious, if they start dying. Just max out Street Trading and don't worry about money. 
Candles - no idea where to get them. Altars, useless so far. 
Books, fairly useless especially since range of skills is determined by the special attribute. You have 5 skills for each character, but in the end none of them do anything. My might characters, do I even care if they are skilled in business, writing etc? Do I care if they are mean, beautiful etc.
Writing only helps to pass an exam and get a job with the gov. That in the end costs you money, since the gov demands money from the city, the city gets upset, if you let it get upset you lose your job. You have to pay the citizens from your money. The only upside of this is that you can go to war and give a military title to ONLY ONE of your characters. You cannot take 2 generals in battle, only one. Who knows why. 

Overall the game seems fine but when you look at it nothing of the mechanics make sense overall and there is no general objective besides moving pixels on a screen.
